bibl.title: Alfonso Gagliardi v. T.W. Lynch. Memorandum
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The District Court of the United States, Western District of Washington, Northern Division

div1.p: The Matter of the Application of Alfonso Gagliardi for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
1. That he was a person likely to become a public charge at the time of entry.
2. That he entered without inspection by means of false and misleading statements.
3. Unable to read the English language or some other language.
The last charge laid that he was unable to read some language will be first considered.
"All aliens over sixteen years of age
"Who cannot read the English language or some other language."
"whether such relative can read or not,"
There is no mention of interpretation or understanding.
This provision does not seem to be included in Sec. 19 (p 20*)

EXEMPTION: "All aliens who have been lawfully (p 6 last line) admitted to the U.S. and who have resided therein continuously for five years and who return to the U.S. within six months from the date of their departure therefrom."
The applicant here read in Italian.
That he was not a person likely to become a public charge.
(1) Has three brothers living near Seattle.
(2) One brother has lived here fourteen years,
(3) Petitioner made $2,000 during preceding in America-- this went back on the land.
(4) Has lease with his brother on forty-three acres of valuable land,
Sec. 19. "Any alien who within five years after the entry becomes a public charge."
"Must be accompanied by the certificate of the individual in charge of the public institution"
That he entered without inspection by means of false and misleading statements.
The applicant re-entered the U.S. at Blaine.
He was protected by every provision of Sec. 19 of the Act.
The petitioner first arrived at New York in 1915.
touching the right of any alien to enter, re-enter
"production of books, papers and documents touching the right of any alien to enter, or re-enter etc. the U.S.
Registered as a soldier in the Army of the U.S.
Entitled to claim re-admission under Act of Congress Approved October 19, 1918. Page 32 of Pamphlet.
"a compulsory enrollment of men for military service."
No conflict, no confusion in oral testimony.
Kwock Jan Fat vs. White 253 U.S. 454

"The Acts of Congress give great power to the Secretary of Labor over Chinese immigrants and persons of Chinese descent. It is a power to be administered, not arbitrarily and secretly, but fairly and openly, under the restraints of the traditions and principles of free government applicable where the fundamental rights of men are involved, regardless of their origin or race. It is the province of the Courts, in proceedings for review, within the limits amply defined in the cases cited, to prevent abuse of this extraordinary power, and this possible only when a full record is preserved of the essentials on which the executive officers proceed to judgment. For failure to preserve such a record for the information, not less of the Commissioner of Immigration and the Secretary of Labor than for the Courts, the judgment in this case must be reversed."
In the United States District Court for the Western District of Washington
In the Matter of the Application of Alfonso Gagliardi for Writ of Habeas Corpus
